title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West

folder: Washington Square & Washington Square West, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square, showing arch
Date: About 1920
Photographer: Jessie Tarbox Beals
title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West

folder: Washington Square & Washington Square West, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Arch, Washington Square, seen from the north so as to show the Judson Memorial Baptist Church (1892) framed in the archway, and the fountain in the center of the park. The church stands on the S.W. corner of Thompson Street and Washington Square South (4th Street).
This arch was built around 1890; the wooden one designed by Stanford White for the Centenary of President Washington's inauguration, in 1889, was so well liked that it was decided to erect a permanent arch of stone, which White also designed.
About 1925.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West

folder: Washington Square North & 4th Street (West), Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square Park, northeastern quarter and eastern side, showing 13-1 Washington Square North and all of Washington Square East.

In the foreground may be seen the bust of Alexander L. Holley; in the right foreground stands the old wooden comfort station, to be replaced in a couple of years by a new stone structure. East of the fountain is the statue of Garibaldi. At the left stands Washington Arch, designed by Stanford White and completed in permanent form around 1891.

The buildings shown, from right to left, are the Vischer building at 78 Washington Square East, N.E. corner of 4th Street, the former Benedick apartment house and the former Celluloid Company building, now part of New York University, on the site of the Asbury Methodist-Episcopal Church. From Washington to Waverly Places the new New York University building (about 1900), on the site of the old building, takes up the block. On Washington Square North are the old residences most of which antedate the Civil War.

On the N.E. corner of University and Waverly Places, diagonally opposite the corner of the Square, a tall apartment building will be erected in 1929.

About 1925.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)

folder: Washington Square West & 4th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square West, from 4th Street to Washington Place, showing the twin 7-story buildings of the Holley Hotel in the center of the block. This is one of the three original Knott hotels, and was named after Alexander J. Holley, of whom a bust has stood in Washington Square since 1890.
The 3-story building on the corner of Washington Place, a part of the hotel, will be torn down in 1930 and replaced by the 16-story Holley Chambers. The three houses in the southern half of the block will also be replaced by a tall apartment building.
December 28, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 4th Street

folder: Washington Square North & 4th Street (West), Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square North, east from about 8 Washington Square. These old residences contrast with the recently erected 21-story apartment building on the N.E. corner of Waverly Place and University Place, built in 1929. In the right foreground is shown part of Washington Arch, giving a very good profile view of Washington.

About 1931.

Ewing Galloway.

THE NEW 'ORK
PUBLIC LIBRARY
ASTOR, LENOX AND TILDEN FOUNDATIONS
R L
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)

folder: Washington Square & Washington Square West, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square, seen from a roof at Sixth Avenue near 4th Street. The principal New York University building is on Washington Square East from Washington to Waverly Places. On the N.E. corner of Waverly and University Places a tall apartment building is going to be erected in 1929. The tall building north of the square is the new One Fifth Avenue. To the right may be seen the new apartment building at 32 Washington Square West, recently erected onto the site of the old Hicks-Lord house. Behind it, on the horizon, the tower of the Consolidated Gas building, Irving Place and 14th Street, is nearing completion. Nearer in the foreground are the roofs of the Holley Hotel, 35-6 Washington Square West, and the old houses 37-39, which are soon to be replaced by an apartment building. The spires in the immediate foreground belong to the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church at 135 West Fourth Street. Down in the park, to the right of the fountain, and nearer, may be seen the newly rebuilt comfort station.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Sixth Avenue, West side, at West 4th Street, north west from Third Street, showing the Excelsior Accordion Manufacturing Company's building.

P.L. Sperr,

April 3, 1928.

March 15th, 1932.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West

title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West

folder: Washington Square North & 4th Street (West), Manhattan, NY
text:
25-19 Washington Square North, seen across the N.E. corner of the Square, some of the oldest remaining houses.
March 15, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)

text:
146 West 4th Street, south side, between Macdougal Street and Sixth Avenue, occupied by a typical Greenwich Village restaurant. May 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

West 4th Street, south side, west from and including MacDougal Street, to Sixth Ave.
May 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Washington Square West & 4th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square West, from 4th Street to Waverly Place, inclusive, showing the old Hotel Holley buildings in the middle of the southern block, with a new building on either side, and the new apartment hotels in the northern block.
At 103 Waverly Place, adjoining the Earle Annex on the N.W. corner, is the Hotel Earle, built around 1905.

February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 4th Street

folder: Washington Square North & 4th Street (West), Manhattan, NY
text:
20-14 and 13-1 Washington Square North, seen from a tall building on Washington Square West, showing the N.E. corner of the Square and the East Side skyline. Part of the New York University building on the S.E. corner of Waverly Place is visible beside the new l University Place apartment house on the N.E. corner. To the left of One Fifth Avenue is the Hotel Brevoort at the N.E. corner of Fifth Avenue and 8th Street, and behind the N.W. shoulder of One Fifth Avenue is the tower of the Consolidated Gas Building on Fourteenth Street.

August, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)

folder: Washington Square & Washington Square West, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square:  The northeasterly corner of same, view-ing northward from a point on it's easterly boundary, Wash-ington Square East, at Washington Place.  In the left back-ground is the towering apartment house, No.1 Fifth Avenue.

October 14, 1939
No's. 1-8

P. L. Sperr
